Requirements: - `account` cannot be the zero address."},"balanceOfBatch(address[],uint256[])":{"details":"See {IERC1155-balanceOfBatch}. Requirements: - `accounts` and `ids` must have the same length."},"getRoleAdmin(bytes32)":{"details":"Returns the admin role that controls `role`. See {grantRole} and {revokeRole}. To change a role's admin, use {_setRoleAdmin}."},"grantRole(bytes32,address)":{"details":"Grants `role` to `account`. If `account` had not been already granted `role`, emits a {RoleGranted} event. Requirements: - the caller must have ``role``'s admin role."},"hasRole(bytes32,address)":{"details":"Returns `true` if `account` has been granted `role`."},"renounceRole(bytes32,address)":{"details":"Revokes `role` from the calling account. Roles are often managed via {grantRole} and {revokeRole}: this function's purpose is to provide a mechanism for accounts to lose their privileges if they are compromised (such as when a trusted device is misplaced). If the calling account had been granted `role`, emits a {RoleRevoked} event. Requirements: - the caller must be `account`."},"revokeRole(bytes32,address)":{"details":"Revokes `role` from `account`. If `account` had been granted `role`, emits a {RoleRevoked} event. Requirements: - the caller must have ``role``'s admin role."},"safeBatchTransferFrom(address,address,uint256[],uint256[],bytes)":{"details":"See {IERC1155-safeBatchTransferFrom}."},"safeTransferFrom(address,address,uint256,uint256,bytes)":{"details":"See {IERC1155-safeTransferFrom}."},"setApprovalForAll(address,bool)":{"details":"See {IERC1155-setApprovalForAll}."},"uri(uint256)":{"details":"See {IERC1155MetadataURI-uri}. This implementation returns the same URI for *all* token types. It relies on the token type ID substitution mechanism https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-1155#metadata[defined in the EIP]. Clients calling this function must replace the `\\{id\\}` substring with the actual token type ID."}},"version":1},"userdoc":{"events":{"JointAccountShareCreated(address,address,uint256)":{"notice":"Notify that a Joint Account was created at the address `account`. One such event is emitted for each owner, including his fraction of the account in basis points (1% of 1%)."},"Transfer(address,address,uint256)":{"notice":"ERC20 Transfer event for bridging this ERC1155 contract to ERC20 on Ethereum."}},"kind":"user","methods":{"BASIS_POINTS()":{"notice":"The total fraction representing 100% of an account."},"CURRENCY()":{"notice":"The token ID that represents the CERE currency for all payments in this contract. "},"CURRENCY_SUPPLY()":{"notice":"The global supply of CERE tokens on all chains. That is 10 billion tokens, with 10 decimals."},"balanceOfJAOwner(address,address)":{"notice":"Calculate the amount of tokens that an owner of a Joint Account can withdraw right now."},"childChainManagerProxy()":{"notice":"The address of the Polygon bridge contract that is allowed to deposit tokens. "},"createJointAccount(address[],uint256[])":{"notice":"Create an account such that multiple owners have a claim on their respective share. The size of a share is given as a fraction in basis points (1% of 1%). The sum of share fractions must equal 10,000. Anyone can create Joint Accounts including any owners."},"currencyInBridge()":{"notice":"Return the total amount of currency available in the bridge, which can be deposited into this contract."},"deposit(address,bytes)":{"notice":"Deposit currency from Ethereum into a user account in this contract. This is implemented by moving tokens from the bridge account to the user account. Two events will be emitted: ERC20 Transfer for the relayers, and ERC1155 TransferSingle like all transfers. There is an extra encoding necessary for the amount. In JavaScript, add this: `web3.eth.abi.encodeParameter('uint256', amount)`"},"distributeJointAccount(address)":{"notice":"Distribute all tokens available to all owners of a Joint Account. The function createJointAccount must be called beforehand. Anyone can trigger the distribution."},"fractionOfJAOwner(address,address)":{"notice":"Return the fraction of an account owned by the given address, in basis points (1% of 1%). If the account does not exist, or if the given address is not an owner of it, this returns 0. If the owner appears more than once in the account, this reports only the first share."},"getNftId(address,uint32,uint64)":{"notice":"Calculate the ID of an NFT type, identifying its issuer, its supply, and an arbitrary nonce."},"isApprovedForAll(address,address)":{"notice":"Return true for operators with the role TRANSFER_OPERATOR. Otherwise, apply the standard approval logic of ERC1155. See {IERC1155-isApprovedForAll}."},"issuanceNonces(address)":{"notice":"A counter of NFT types issued by each issuer. This is used to generate unique NFT IDs."},"issue(uint64,bytes)":{"notice":"Issue a supply of NFTs of a new type, and return its ID. No more NFT of this type can be issued again. The caller will be recorded as the issuer and it will initially own the entire supply."},"makeAddressOfJointAccount(address[],uint256[])":{"notice":"Generate a unique address identifying a list of owners and shares. It may be used to predict the address of a Joint Account and receive payments even before calling the function createJointAccount."},"supportsInterface(bytes4)":{"notice":"Supports interfaces of AccessControl, ERC1155, and ERC1155 MetadataURI."},"updateChildChainManager(address)":{"notice":"Change the ChainManager, which can deposit currency into any account. Only the current ChainManager is allowed to change the ChainManager."},"withdraw(uint256)":{"notice":"Withdraw currency from a user account in this contract to Ethereum. This is implemented by moving tokens from the user account to the bridge account. Two events will be emitted: ERC20 Transfer for the relayers, and ERC1155 TransferSingle like all transfers."}},"notice":"A Joint Account (JA) is an account such that multiple owners have a claim on their respective share of the funds. Joint Accounts support the contract currency only. They cannot be used for NFTs. An owner may be another Joint Account, or a smart contract. It is possible to withdraw funds through nested JAs, because anyone can trigger a withdrawal from a JA to its owners, including if that owner is itself a JA. documentation.text:
A Joint Account (JA) is an account such that multiple owners have a claim on their respective share of the funds.
Joint Accounts support the contract currency only. They cannot be used for NFTs.
An owner may be another Joint Account, or a smart contract.
It is possible to withdraw funds through nested JAs,
because anyone can trigger a withdrawal from a JA to its owners,
including if that owner is itself a JA.
[An implementation that distributes to all owners at once.]
The total fraction representing 100% of an account.

Notify that a Joint Account was created at the address `account`.
 One such event is emitted for each owner, including his fraction of the account in basis points (1% of 1%).

typeDescriptions.typeString: literal_string "Arrays of owners and fractions must have the same length"

arguments.value: Arrays of owners and fractions must have the same length

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "Arrays of owners and fractions must have the same length"

documentation.text:
Create an account such that multiple owners have a claim on their respective share.
 The size of a share is given as a fraction in basis points (1% of 1%). The sum of share fractions must equal 10,000.
 Anyone can create Joint Accounts including any owners.

typeDescriptions.typeString: mapping(address => struct JointAccounts.JointAccountShare storage ref[] storage ref)
struct JointAccounts.JointAccountShare storage ref[] storage ref
struct JointAccounts.JointAccountShare storage ref[] storage pointer
struct JointAccounts.JointAccountShare storage ref[] storage pointer

documentation.text:
Distribute all tokens available to all owners of a Joint Account.
 The function createJointAccount must be called beforehand.
 Anyone can trigger the distribution.

Generate a unique address identifying a list of owners and shares.
 It may be used to predict the address of a Joint Account and receive payments
 even before calling the function createJointAccount.

typeDescriptions.typeString: mapping(address => struct JointAccounts.JointAccountShare storage ref[] storage ref)
struct JointAccounts.JointAccountShare storage ref[] storage ref
struct JointAccounts.JointAccountShare storage ref[] storage pointer
struct JointAccounts.JointAccountShare storage ref[] storage pointer

documentation.text:
Return the fraction of an account owned by the given address, in basis points (1% of 1%).
 If the account does not exist, or if the given address is not an owner of it, this returns 0.
 If the owner appears more than once in the account, this reports only the first share.
Calculate the amount of tokens that an owner of a Joint Account can withdraw right now.

A Joint Account (JA) is an account such that multiple owners have a claim on their respective share of the funds.
Joint Accounts support the contract currency only. They cannot be used for NFTs.
An owner may be another Joint Account, or a smart contract.
It is possible to withdraw funds through nested JAs,
because anyone can trigger a withdrawal from a JA to its owners,
including if that owner is itself a JA.
[An implementation that distributes to all owners at once.]
The total fraction representing 100% of an account.

Notify that a Joint Account was created at the address `account`.
 One such event is emitted for each owner, including his fraction of the account in basis points (1% of 1%).

documentation.text:
Create an account such that multiple owners have a claim on their respective share.
 The size of a share is given as a fraction in basis points (1% of 1%). The sum of share fractions must equal 10,000.
 Anyone can create Joint Accounts including any owners.

documentation.text:
Distribute all tokens available to all owners of a Joint Account.
 The function createJointAccount must be called beforehand.
 Anyone can trigger the distribution.

Generate a unique address identifying a list of owners and shares.
 It may be used to predict the address of a Joint Account and receive payments
 even before calling the function createJointAccount.

documentation.text:
Return the fraction of an account owned by the given address, in basis points (1% of 1%).
 If the account does not exist, or if the given address is not an owner of it, this returns 0.
 If the owner appears more than once in the account, this reports only the first share.
Calculate the amount of tokens that an owner of a Joint Account can withdraw right now.

balanceOf(address,uint256).details: See {IERC1155-balanceOf}. Requirements: - `account` cannot be the zero address.

balanceOfBatch(address[],uint256[]).details: See {IERC1155-balanceOfBatch}. Requirements: - `accounts` and `ids` must have the same length.

getRoleAdmin(bytes32).details: Returns the admin role that controls `role`. See {grantRole} and {revokeRole}. To change a role's admin, use {_setRoleAdmin}.

grantRole(bytes32,address).details: Grants `role` to `account`. If `account` had not been already granted `role`, emits a {RoleGranted} event. Requirements: - the caller must have ``role``'s admin role.

renounceRole(bytes32,address).details: Revokes `role` from the calling account. Roles are often managed via {grantRole} and {revokeRole}: this function's purpose is to provide a mechanism for accounts to lose their privileges if they are compromised (such as when a trusted device is misplaced). If the calling account had been granted `role`, emits a {RoleRevoked} event. Requirements: - the caller must be `account`.

revokeRole(bytes32,address).details: Revokes `role` from `account`. If `account` had been granted `role`, emits a {RoleRevoked} event. Requirements: - the caller must have ``role``'s admin role.

uri(uint256).details: See {IERC1155MetadataURI-uri}. This implementation returns the same URI for *all* token types. It relies on the token type ID substitution mechanism https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-1155#metadata[defined in the EIP]. Clients calling this function must replace the `\{id\}` substring with the actual token type ID.

JointAccountShareCreated(address,address.notice: Notify that a Joint Account was created at the address `account`. One such event is emitted for each owner, including his fraction of the account in basis points (1% of 1%).

Transfer(address,address,uint256).notice: ERC20 Transfer event for bridging this ERC1155 contract to ERC20 on Ethereum.

BASIS_POINTS().notice: The total fraction representing 100% of an account.

CURRENCY().notice: The token ID that represents the CERE currency for all payments in this contract.

CURRENCY_SUPPLY().notice: The global supply of CERE tokens on all chains. That is 10 billion tokens, with 10 decimals.

balanceOfJAOwner(address,address).notice: Calculate the amount of tokens that an owner of a Joint Account can withdraw right now.

childChainManagerProxy().notice: The address of the Polygon bridge contract that is allowed to deposit tokens.

createJointAccount(address[],uint256[]).notice: Create an account such that multiple owners have a claim on their respective share. The size of a share is given as a fraction in basis points (1% of 1%). The sum of share fractions must equal 10,000. Anyone can create Joint Accounts including any owners.

currencyInBridge().notice: Return the total amount of currency available in the bridge, which can be deposited into this contract.

deposit(address,bytes).notice: Deposit currency from Ethereum into a user account in this contract. This is implemented by moving tokens from the bridge account to the user account. Two events will be emitted: ERC20 Transfer for the relayers, and ERC1155 TransferSingle like all transfers. There is an extra encoding necessary for the amount. In JavaScript, add this: `web3.eth.abi.encodeParameter('uint256', amount)`

distributeJointAccount(address).notice: Distribute all tokens available to all owners of a Joint Account. The function createJointAccount must be called beforehand. Anyone can trigger the distribution.

fractionOfJAOwner(address,address).notice: Return the fraction of an account owned by the given address, in basis points (1% of 1%). If the account does not exist, or if the given address is not an owner of it, this returns 0. If the owner appears more than once in the account, this reports only the first share.

getNftId(address,uint32,uint64).notice: Calculate the ID of an NFT type, identifying its issuer, its supply, and an arbitrary nonce.

isApprovedForAll(address,address).notice: Return true for operators with the role TRANSFER_OPERATOR. Otherwise, apply the standard approval logic of ERC1155. See {IERC1155-isApprovedForAll}.

issuanceNonces(address).notice: A counter of NFT types issued by each issuer. This is used to generate unique NFT IDs.

issue(uint64,bytes).notice: Issue a supply of NFTs of a new type, and return its ID. No more NFT of this type can be issued again. The caller will be recorded as the issuer and it will initially own the entire supply.

makeAddressOfJointAccount(address[],uint.notice: Generate a unique address identifying a list of owners and shares. It may be used to predict the address of a Joint Account and receive payments even before calling the function createJointAccount.

supportsInterface(bytes4).notice: Supports interfaces of AccessControl, ERC1155, and ERC1155 MetadataURI.

updateChildChainManager(address).notice: Change the ChainManager, which can deposit currency into any account. Only the current ChainManager is allowed to change the ChainManager.

withdraw(uint256).notice: Withdraw currency from a user account in this contract to Ethereum. This is implemented by moving tokens from the user account to the bridge account. Two events will be emitted: ERC20 Transfer for the relayers, and ERC1155 TransferSingle like all transfers.

userdoc.notice: A Joint Account (JA) is an account such that multiple owners have a claim on their respective share of the funds. Joint Accounts support the contract currency only. They cannot be used for NFTs. An owner may be another Joint Account, or a smart contract. It is possible to withdraw funds through nested JAs, because anyone can trigger a withdrawal from a JA to its owners, including if that owner is itself a JA. [An implementation that distributes to all owners at once.]
